question: The New York and Rhode Island assemblies have been dissolved...
answer: The middle colonies?

question: Rioting both sides of the bay, in Chestertown they burned the Customs House and tar-and-feathered the Customs Agent. He died of burns. In Wilmington they killed a Royal Magistrate and two Redcoats.
answer: Anything about the convention in Philadelphia?

question: Welcome! Welcome! Margaret, William, look at you...! They're huge. What have you been feeding them?
answer: They're from good stock on their mother's side.

question: Thank you. Come, come, inside, wait until you see what I have... Inside, inside...
answer: You look well, Charlotte.

question: As do you.
answer: Inside, all of you... Very well.

question: What news?
answer: The British army is barricaded in Boston. Harry Lee, is here from Virginia, recruiting for a Continental Army.

question: Is that why the Assembly was convened?
answer: Yes. He seeks a levy of troops and money.

question: And the Governor?
answer: He vowed that if the Assembly votes a single shilling to Lee, he'll dissolve the body.

question: You all know why I am here. I am not an orator and I will not try to convince you of the worthiness of our cause. I am a soldier and we are at war and with the declaration of independence we all expect from Philadelphia, it will soon be a formal state of war. In preparation for that, eight of the thirteen colonies have levied money in support of a Continental Army. I ask South Carolina to be the ninth. Massachusetts and New Hampshire are not as far from South Carolina as you might think and the war they're fighting is not for independence of one or two colonies. It's for the independence of a nation.
answer: An American nation. Colonel Lee, with your permission?

question: Please.
answer: Those of us who call ourselves Patriots are not seeking to give birth to an American nation, but to protect one that already exists. It was born a hundred-and-seventy years ago at Jamestown, Virginia and has grown stronger and more mature with every generation reared and with every crop sown and harvested. We are a nation and our rights as citizens of that nation are threatened by a tyrant three thousand miles away.

question: An elected legislature can trample a man's rights just as easily as a King can.
answer: Captain Marion, I understood you to be a Patriot.

question: It's Mister Marion.
answer: I understood him to be a Patriot as well.

question: You were an Englishman then...
answer: I was an American, I just didn't know it yet...

question: We don't have to go to war to gain independence...
answer: Balderdash!

question: There are a thousand avenues, other than war, at our disposal...
answer: Name five hundred.

question: Royal petition, delegates to court, judicial redress, economic boycott, bribery...
answer: That's five, keep going...

question: ... time, royal succession, regicide, bribery...
answer: You said bribery twice...

question: We do not have to go to war to gain independence.
answer: Francis, I was at Bunker Hill. It was as bad as anything you and I saw on the frontier. Worse than the slaughter at the Ashuelot River. The British advanced three times and we killed over seven hundred of them at point blank range. And still, they advanced and they took the ground. That is the measure of their resolve. If your principles dictate independence, then war is the only way. It has come to that.

question: I have seven children. My wife is dead. Who's to care for them if I go to war?
answer: Wars are not fought only by childless men. A man must weigh his personal responsibilities against his principles.

question: That's what I'm doing. I will not fight and because I won't, I will not cast a vote that will send others to fight in my stead.
answer: And your principles?

question: Nay.
answer: Father, I've lost respect for you. I thought you were a man of principle.

question: When you have children, I hope you'll understand.
answer: When I have children, I hope I don't hide behind them.

question: Do you intend to enlist without my permission?
answer: Yes.

question: One of yours?
answer: Gabriel.

question: I recognize him now. Is he as imprudent as his father was at his age?
answer: No, thank the Lord. He's more like his mother.

question: I'll see to it that he serves under me.
answer: Thank you.

question: Not yet, Thomas.
answer: When?

question: Seventeen.
answer: But it's already been two years and that's two more years. The war could be over by then.

question: God willing.
answer: Alright. Seventeen.

question: Just east of it.
answer: Are we safe here?

question: Don't worry.
answer: We could go stay at Aunt Charlotte's farm. She's to the west.

question: Margaret, get bandages and water. Thomas, the porch, eyes open.
answer: Have you seen any Redcoats?

question: Not yet. What happened?
answer: It wasn't like Saratoga. There, we stayed in the trees, but this time Gates marched us straight at the Redcoats. They fired two volleys into us and we broke like straw. I was given these dispatches... I saw Virginia Regulars surrender... as they laid down their weapons the British Green Dragoons rode into them and hacked them to bits... killed them all, over two hundred men.

question: They had surrendered?
answer: I have to get these dispatches to Hillsboro.

question: You're in no condition to ride.
answer: I have no choice, I...

question: Sleep, now.
answer: Father... I killed those men...

question: Don't blame yourself, you did what I told you to do.
answer: I'm glad I killed them... I'm glad...

question: They're asleep.
answer: How did this... how did I let this happen?

question: You couldn't have known.
answer: I should have known... once I would have... I used to be wary... and today I watched my son killed before my eyes... your sister civilized me and I damn myself for having let her...

question: Thomas is dead but you've done nothing for which you should be ashamed.
answer: I've done nothing and for that I am ashamed.

question: If you go, I'll care for them as if they were my own.
answer: I'll leave in the morning with Gabriel.

question: It's already over.
answer: Damn you, Sergeant, don't move the wounded twice, put them straight on the wagons from the surgeons. Lieutenant, detail men for outriders. We move out as soon as the wounded are ready.

question: Green Dragoons came to my home, killed my son, Thomas. It was Tarleton himself.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: I'm sorry I wasn't here for this.
answer: There's nothing you could have done, Gates is a damned fool.

question: We saw.
answer: I begged him to stay in the cover of the trees but he insisted the only way to break Cornwallis was muzzle- to-muzzle. He spent too many years in the British army.

question: Where is he now?
answer: Last anyone saw, riding hard, northeast, his staff a hundred yards behind, trying to catch up.

question: Who's in command?
answer: I am, I think.

question: What are my orders?
answer: If you want orders, I've got some for you. We're a breath away from losing this war. In the North, Washington is reeling from Valley Forge, running and hiding from Clinton and twelve thousand Redcoats. Here in the South, Cornwallis has broken our back. He captured over five thousand of our troops when he took Charleston and today he destroyed the only army that stood between him and New York.

question: So now Cornwallis will head north, link up with Clinton and finish off Washington.
answer: And Patriots will start dying on the gallows instead of the battlefield. Unless we can keep Cornwallis in the South until the French arrive. A treaty was signed at Versailles after our victory at Saratoga. The French are sending a fleet and ten thousand troops.

question: When?
answer: Fall, six months at the earliest.

question: Long time.
answer: The bigger problem is where, not when. The French fleet won't sail north of the Chesapeake for fear of early storms.

question: So you're going to try to keep Cornwallis in the South until then.
answer: Not me, you. I'm going north with every Continental regular I can find to reinforce Washington or he won't last six weeks.

question: You expect Cornwallis to be held here by militia?
answer: Not held, just slowed down.

question: They're nothing but farmers and you're asking them to try to keep a tiger in their backyard. They'd be better off letting it move on.
answer: They'd be better off, but the cause wouldn't be.

question: How many men does Cornwallis have under his command?
answer: Four thousand infantry and around six hundred cavalry... ... including the Green Dragoons under Tarleton.

question: I'll do what I can.
answer: I'm giving you a field commission as a colonel.

question: What now, sir?
answer: We put out the word. We'll start along the south side of the Santee...

question: We'd cover more ground if we split up.
answer: It's safer if we stay together.

question: Colonel, I didn't request this transfer because you're my father. I requested it because I believe in this cause and this is where I can do the most good.
answer: Oh?

question: I've been doing this for two years. I'm the best scout in the Continental Army, the best horseman, the best shot, the best scavenger and I know every deer path and swamp trail between here and Charleston.
answer: Is that so?

question: Yes, sir. My father taught me.
answer: Did your father teach you humility?

question: He tried. It didn't take.
answer: Alright, Corporal, you take Bennington, Harrisville, Acworth and the farms along Black Swamp. I'll take the north side of the river. We'll meet at Snow's Island.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: And, Corporal... ... be careful.

question: Yes... ... father.
answer: I'm looking for John Billings. If he comes back from the dead, tell him Francis Marion is looking for him. I'll wait. Miracles happen.

question: I'm looking for John Billings. If he comes back from the dead, tell him Francis Marion is looking for him. I'll wait. Miracles happen.
answer: You expect to hold Cornwallis with militia?

question: I expect to try.
answer: Trust you and Harry Lee. Remember that damned overland you two thought up in '62 to hit Fort Louis?

question: It worked. How many men can you raise?
answer: Not many. Dalton, Scott, they've got their reasons; Rev. Oliver, he believes in the cause; some of the young bucks; a few like me with nothing to lose... What about you? You've got a lot to lose.

question: You coming, or not?
answer: Father, this war is about more than Thomas.

question: Is it?
answer: If you're here only for revenge, you're doing a disservice to him as well as yourself.

question: How old are you?
answer: You know how old I am.

question: Reamer, boring tool...
answer: Swage, broach, etching tool...

question: We can rifle those musket barrels...
answer: We'll need a forge...

question: Easy enough...
answer: We've got clay to make a chamber...

question: Oil cloth and barrel staves to make a bellows...
answer: And we can yank a wagon wheel, weight it, rig a piston and drive shaft and we'll have a flywheel to power the bellows...

question: His journals, letters, maps, books... Today was hard earned but a good start. In the future wounded British soldiers will be given quarters.
answer: Like they gave quarter to my family? My wife and three children were hiding in our root cellar when they came. The Redcoats locked the door and torched the house.

question: You have my sympathy... but the order stands.
answer: And who are you to give an order like that? We all know what you did after Fort Wilderness.

question: I'm your commanding officer. This is militia, not regular army. I can't hold you here, but as long as you stay, you'll follow my orders.
answer: Thank you.

question: For what?
answer: For trying to impose some decency on that sort.

question: Why am I here, Colonel Halbert?
answer: For the ball, sir?

question: Why, after six weeks, are we still here to attend a ball. By now, we should be attending balls in North Carolina, not South Carolina.
answer: Our supply line, sir?

question: Halt. Look alive, boys.
answer: Sergeant, this road is closed. Those wagons now belong to the Continental Army.

question: Ready arms! By twos!
answer: Sergeant, there's no reason for you and your men to die. Just leave the wagons and go.

question: Steady, boys... This is the King's highway and I advise you and your men to make way. Prepare to fire.
answer: It's a trap...

question: FIRE!
answer: GO!

question: Father, no...
answer: That's him. Tarleton. Damn you! Let go!

question: Father, please... Fourteen dead, eleven wounded, eighteen captured.
answer: I should have killed him when I had the chance?

question: When was that? In the swamp at the expense of your men? Or when he killed Thomas at the expense of your family?
answer: No...

question: Or perhaps tomorrow at the expense of our cause. There will be a time and a place for revenge but killing Tarleton at the expense of your duty serves no one but yourself. Stay the course.
answer: Stay the course... your mother used to say that to me when I'd get drunk or lose my temper.

question: She'd say it to me when I picked on Thomas or Nathan.
answer: You learned her lessons better than

question: She got me at a more impressionable age.
answer: Next time we'll bring more blankets.

question: That would be nice.
answer: Maybe we'll be lucky this winter and have just rain, no snow.

question: That would be nice, too.
answer: Just because the French didn't come this fall, doesn't mean they're never going to come.

question: Lord Cornwallis will be with you presently.
answer: Thank you.

question: You may, of course, keep your weapons, but I must warn you that...
answer: I'm familiar with appropriate behavior at a military parley.

question: Yes, quite, but you should know that...
answer: That will be all, Major. I'll wait for Lord Cornwallis.

question: Yes... you will wait.
answer: One other thing. The proper form of address to a superior officer, even one of an opposing army, is "Yes, sir."

question: One other thing. The proper form of address to a superior officer, even one of an opposing army, is "Yes, sir."
answer: Jupiter! Mars!

question: Go.
answer: My boys... my boys... you seem to have been well fed. Thank you for that, Colonel.

question: My pleasure, sir.
answer: Please forgive me for keeping you waiting.

question: Apology accepted.
answer: Thank you, Colonel... I'm afraid I don't know your name.

question: Colonel will do.
answer: As you wish. Colonel... Colonel Banastre Tarleton.

question: Shall we proceed?
answer: Let us. Unless you object, I would like to deem this meeting a formal negotiation and, as such, there are certain customary practices. Perhaps I could explain them to you...

question: I'm familiar with how a formal negotiation is handled.
answer: Oh?

question: I served in His Majesty's army in the French and Indian War.
answer: Oh. Very well, then. Would you, as the initiating party, like to begin?

question: Unless you would like to claim aggrieved status.
answer: You are familiar with how these things are done. In fact, I would like to claim aggrieved status.

question: Very well, proceed, sir.
answer: First, you have in your possession certain belongings of mine, including clothing, private papers, furniture and personal effects of a non-military nature which I would like to have returned to me.

question: I will do so as soon as possible.
answer: Thank you.

question: Please accept my apology for not having done so sooner.
answer: Apology accepted. Now, on the matter of the specific targeting of officers during engagements, this is absolutely unacceptable.

question: That one is a bit more difficult.
answer: Certainly you must know that in civilized warfare, officers in the field must not be accorded inappropriate levels of hostile attention.

question: And what are inappropriate levels of hostile attention?
answer: Colonel, imagine the utter chaos that would result from un-led armies having at each other. There must be gentlemen in command to lead and, when appropriate, restrain their men.

question: Restrain them from the targeting of civilians, including women and children?
answer: That is a separate issue.

question: I consider them linked.
answer: I beg to differ. One is a command decision on your part. The other represents nothing more than the occasional over-exuberance of field officers attempting to carry out their duty in difficult circumstances.

question: As long as your soldiers attack civilians, I will order the shooting of your officers at the outset of every engagement. And my men are excellent marksmen.
answer: Very well, let us move on to...

question: Prisoner exchange.
answer: Sir?

question: You have eighteen of my men. I want them back.
answer: I do have eighteen criminals under sentence of death, but I hold no prisoners-of-war.

question: If that's your position, then eighteen of your officers will die. Nineteen, if you hang me with my men.
answer: What officers?

question: In the clearing, just down from the crest, to the left of the dark pines...
answer: Their names, ranks and posts?

question: They refused to give me their names. Their ranks are nine lieutenants, five captains, three majors and one fat colonel who called me a cheeky fellow. Their posts? We picked them up here-and-there last night.
answer: You are not a gentleman.

question: If your conduct is the measure of a gentleman, I take that as a compliment. Get my men.
answer: Arrange the exchange.

question: It's all set.
answer: This will do fine. Thank you. So he's the one they talk about, the Swamp Fox.

question: Yes.
answer: I thought it might be him, the bits and pieces we heard, a veteran, fought in the French and Indian War, knows the swamps.

question: They won't stop looking for you and the children.
answer: We'll be alright, here, for now. How is he?

question: Why didn't he come?
answer: He wanted to, Susan, but he couldn't leave his men.

question: He left us.
answer: I know he did and he's sorry. He'll come back as soon as he can. There are some letters here from him. Some are just to you.

question: I don't care. I hate him.
answer: You don't hate him.

question: She spoke? Susan spoke?
answer: Full sentences. As if she had been speaking all along.

question: I don't believe it... and I wasn't there for it... Tell me everything she said, word for word.
answer: She said... she loves you and misses you but she understands why you can't be there with her.

question: She said that? Oh, my Lord, she said that? Isn't that something.
answer: Father, there's something else I need to talk to you about.

question: What?
answer: Come with me. I'll tell you when we get there. Father, I'm looking for a best man.

question: Sir, I'd like to request a furlough. Two days?
answer: Granted. Where are you going?

question: Cheraw Falls.
answer: It's beautiful there. Your mother and I were there once, before you were born.

question: I know.
answer: She would have been pleased.

question: From General Clinton in New York... "... your request to move north is denied until you have properly dealt with your militia problem." He underlined, 'militia'. "You have spent over six months dealing with a six-week problem. It is essential that you quell the militia..." Underlined again. "... insurgency, particularly because of the likely move south of Washington and the inevitable arrival of the French. Militia, as you have so often pointed out, is not worth the attention of a significant army, hence it is mystifying why militia has bedeviled you for so long..." "... it is my fervent hope that the vigor of your campaign comes to match the vigor of your correspondence with your Parliamentary and Court patrons. Only then might you share in the victory, on the verge of which I now stand." "Your guardedly respectful Commander, General Sir George Clinton." If I fail, you fail.
answer: Perhaps.

question: And if I triumph, you triumph.
answer: Probably.

question: How can we end this madness?
answer: Difficult, sir. This is, as you pointed out, a civil war.

question: Civility is a secondary virtue. It is superseded by duty.
answer: I understand, sir. I believe they are almost ready. Very well, get one of the others.

question: The overlook, up there should be where you post the watch. Work out a schedule. Short watches, especially at night. If you can catch some of those mockingbirds you can make cages and put them along there for alarms. Now let's find someplace to cache extra weapons... Good apple. Very good. Sweet.
answer: May I ask you a question?

question: Yes, of course.
answer: Do you think Frances with an "e" is too manly a name for a girl?

question: No.
answer: Do you think Francis with an "i" is too womanly a name for a boy?

question: No.
answer: Good.

question: When?
answer: Late summer.

question: Congratulations.
answer: Thank you.

question: I'm not my sister.
answer: Excuse me?

question: I said, I'm not my sister.
answer: I know that.

question: Do you?
answer: Of course, I do.

question: Very well, then.
answer: Just a little goodbye? One word? That's all I want to hear. Goodbye, Charlotte.

question: Anne...?
answer: Don't go in there.

question: Is it her? Is Anne in there?
answer: She is. Don't go in there.

question: Father, tell me what happened at Fort Wilderness?
answer: You know what happened.

question: No, I don't.
answer: Everyone knows. It's what made me a hero. Me, Harry Lee, all of us. I got a medal. Men bought me drinks. They still do sometimes. Everyone knows what happened.

question: Tell me what everyone doesn't know.
answer: And what do they know?

question: That the French and Cherokees captured the fort and when you retook it, you took revenge on them for what they did during the occupation.
answer: That's right.

question: That's not enough. Tell me.
answer: Your mother asked me the same question around the time you were born. I was drunk and I was foolish enough to answer her. That's why it was four years between you and Thomas. It took me that long to regain her respect.

question: I'm not my mother. I can't have the respect without the knowing.
answer: It was in '63. It was a bad time. The French and the Cherokee had raided along the Blue Ridge. All the English settlers took refuge at Fort Wilderness but the French captured it. We were sent in relief. Harry Lee, Billings, sixty of us. We already had something of a reputation for being... harsh. When we got there the fort was abandoned. Not a French soldier or Cherokee anywhere. They had left a week earlier. What we found was... bad. They had left the settlers there. The men had been burned alive, the women were in pieces and the children were on stakes. We buried them, then we went to track. It was a cold trail and they were moving fast. We went faster. We caught up to them at Kentucky Ford.

question: Go on.
answer: We took our time with them and gave every one of them worse than they had given at the fort. It was two weeks before they were all dead, all except two. We put the heads on a pallet and had the two we let live take it to the French at Fort Ambercon. The eyes, fingers and tongues we put in a basket and sent that down the Asheulot to the Cherokee. The French stayed east of the Blue Ridge after that and the Cherokee broke their treaty with the French and stayed out of the fight. That seemed to make a difference. The war went another year, things went better... and men bought us drinks. It was a different time, son. And you're a better man than that.

question: I see, do as I say, not as I do.
answer: Yes. If this war is about more than Thomas, it's about more than Anne, as well. Stay the course.

question: You have to bury him. I'll help you bury him.
answer: Don't touch him.

question: How many men have we seen die?
answer: Two. Gabriel and Thomas.

question: They're gone. And there is nothing you or I can do to bring them back. But there is something you can do to help end all this.
answer: It is ended.

question: No. It's not over yet. Two days ride, Yorktown, Virginia. Washington, the French, Cornwallis and Tarleton. It will end, one way or another. Francis, nothing will replace your sons but helping us will justify their sacrifice.
answer: Take this to General Washington.

question: Take this to General Washington.
answer: Did you bring me this? Take this to Colonel Marion.

question: Colonel Francis Marion. Gray.
answer: Earned. Come. I have something I want to show you. Gentlemen. I was sorry to hear about your son.

question: I lost another a year ago, Thomas. He was only fifteen.
answer: I've had no sons to lose, nor daughters. I lose the sons of other men. Life was easier when we only had ourselves to get killed. Gentlemen, what do we see? Francis, tell me about General Cornwallis.

question: Remember Braddock?
answer: That bad?

question: Worse.
answer: Proud, priggish and competent. A very bad combination in an adversary. For those of you who don't know, we intercepted a British dispatch this morning. General Clinton has sailed from New York to relieve Cornwallis. Less than a week. Sixteen ships and over nine thousand Redcoats. And when the British ships arrive, the French ships will flee. And when the French ships flee, General Rochambeau and the French troops will flee as well.

question: Then you must let the message go through.
answer: If Cornwallis receives news that Clinton is coming, he'll simply hold tight and wait. He'll fight a purely defensive battle and he'll win that.

question: No, he won't. There are two things you need to know about Cornwallis. First, he is a very proud man, He would rather risk defeat than share a victory. If you give him what he thinks is an out, he'll take it.
answer: And what is the second thing?

question: Goodbye, Francis.
answer: Goodbye, Harry. And congratulations on the birth of your son.

question: Thank you. Maybe all of this will buy him some peace.
answer: I hope so. Your son, what did you name him?

question: Robert. Robert E. Lee.
answer: A good name for a farmer. Two pounds, fourteen ounces.
